title: Economics: Goods and Services

vocab.definition: Things that people make or grow that we can buy
Jobs that people do to help others
A person who makes or grows goods
A person who buys and uses goods and services
Giving one thing to get another thing

teachingNotes: Use examples from students' daily lives to distinguish between goods and services. Discuss jobs in the community and whether they provide goods or services. Practice identifying producers and consumers in different scenarios.

sample.question: What is the difference between goods and services?
expectedAny: goods are things, services are jobs

sample.question: Give an example of a service.
Who is a producer?
expectedAny: a person who makes or grows goods

sample.question: Who is a consumer?
expectedAny: a person who buys and uses goods and services

sample.question: What does trade mean?
expectedAny: giving one thing to get another

sample.question: Name a service you used this week.

truefalse.question: A haircut is an example of goods.
A toy is an example of goods.
Services are objects you can touch.

multiplechoice.question: Which of these is a service?
Which shows trade?
choices: Giving a toy for a snack

multiplechoice.question: Which could be goods at a store?

fillintheblank.question: A baker is a ________ because they make bread.
A person who buys things is a ________.
Services are ________ people do to help others.
Goods are ________ you can buy and touch.
A farmer who grows apples is a ________.
A person buying apples is a ________.

shortanswer.question: Give an example of trading goods or services.
Name two services your family uses.
How are producers and consumers connected?
expectedAny: producers make goods that consumers buy

shortanswer.question: What goods do you use at school?
What service helps keep you healthy?
Why do people trade?
expectedAny: to get what they need or want

shortanswer.question: What is one job that provides a service?
